facts.text: Appellant-company appointed the respondent as a staff correspondent at Gauhati by letter dated January 16, 1953 on basic salary of Rs. 300, dearness allowance at 40% and fixed conveyance allowance of Rs. 100 per month.

This appeal, by special leave, is directed against the award of the Labour Court, Delhi in a reference made to it under S. 17  2  of the Working Journalists  Conditions of Service  and Miscellaneous Provisions Act, 1955  referred to hereinafter as the Act.

issues.text: Whether the respondent, not being in the company's employment at the time he filed his claim, was a working journalist entitled to the provisions of the Working Journalists Act

anchor.surface_text: The first contention raised by counsel for the company against the award was that the respondent, not being in the company's employment at the time he filed his claim in the Labour Court, was not a working journalist,

issues.text: Whether the receipt in full settlement estopped the respondent from claiming compensation for leave

anchor.surface_text: The Labour Court rejected the company's plea that the receipt given by the respondent in full settlement of all his claims estopped him from making these claims on the ground that as these items were claimable under the Act there could be no estoppel against law.

holdings.text: an ex-employee would for the purposes of the present controversy be a working journalist

anchor.surface_text: Since the definitions of ex employee in these two Acts were in language similar to the one used in the present Act, these decisions would be authorities for the view that an ex- employee would for the purposes of the present controversy be a working journalist.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedents like Western India Automobile and Central Provinces treat dismissed ex-employee as workman for disputes; definitions subject to context; distinguished Dharangadhara and Dimakuchi

holdings.text: The scheme of all these acts dealing with industrial questions is to permit an ex-employee to avail of the benefits of their provisions, the only requirement being that the claim in dispute must be one which has arisen or accrued whilst the claimant was in the employment of the person against whom it is made

anchor.surface_text: The scheme of all these acts dealing with industrial questions is to permit an ex-employee to avail of the benefits of their provisions, the only requirement being that the claim in dispute must be one which has arisen or accrued whilst the claimant was in the employment of the person against whom it is made.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Provisions in ss.5,17(1) WJ Act and s.33C(1) ID Act contemplate post-termination recovery by ex-employee or heirs; definitions qualified by 'unless context otherwise requires'

holdings.text: The rule of estoppel thus could not be invoked against the claim for compensation for leave period

holdings.reasoning_summary: No representation or waiver by respondent; company relied on rules not produced; no adjustment against notice mentioned

holdings.text: The plea of estoppel made on behalf of the company, therefore, cannot be accepted

anchor.surface_text: Likewise, the benefit of the telephone and newspapers was allowed to the respondent not merely for the use thereof in connection with his employment or duties connected with it. Both the car allowance and the benefit of the free telephone and newspapers appear to have been allowed to him to directly reduce the expenditure which would otherwise have gone into his family budget

holdings.reasoning_summary: Fall under ID Act s.2(rr) imported via WJ Act s.2(g): allowances and amenities; reduce family expenditure, relevant for fair wages

precedents.citation: Western India Automobile Association v. Industrial Tribunal 1

anchor.surface_text: Western India Automobile Association v. Industrial Tribunal 1 . The companytention there was that in the light of the definitions of industrial dispute and an employee as they stood in the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947 before the Amending Act 36 of 1956 was passed, a dispute as to reinstatement of a discharged or dismissed workman companyld number fall within the scope of an industrial dispute.

precedents.case_name: Western India Automobile Association v. Industrial Tribunal
precedents.cited_proposition: the definition of industrial dispute used the words employment or nonemployment, that whereas one was a positive, the other was a negative act of an employer, that such an act related to an existing employment or to an existing non-employment
precedents.cited_holding: The failure to employ or the refusal to employ are actions on the part of the employer which would be covered by the term employment or non-employment. Reinstatement is connected with non-employment and is therefore within the words of the definition.

precedents.citation: Central Provinces Transport Services Ltd. vs. Raghunath 2

anchor.surface_text: Central Provinces Transport Services Ltd. vs. Raghunath 2  in companynection with the C.P. Berar Industrial Disputes Settlement Act, XXIII of 1947.

precedents.case_name: Central Provinces Transport Services Ltd. vs. Raghunath
precedents.cited_proposition: a dispute between an employer and an employee regarding the latters dismissal and reinstatement would be an industrial dispute within s. 2 12  of that Act

precedents.citation: Dharangadhara Chemical Works Ltd. v. State of Saurashtra 2

anchor.surface_text: Dharangadhara Chemical Works Ltd. v. State of Saurashtra 2  and Workmen v. The Management of Dimakuchi Tea Estate 3 . In Dharangadhara Chemical Works Ltd., the appellants were lessees holding a licence for manufacturing salt on the demised lands.

precedents.case_name: Dharangadhara Chemical Works Ltd. v. State of Saurashtra
precedents.cited_proposition: The essential condition of a person being a workman within the terms of this definition is that he should be employed to do the work in that industry, that there should be, in other words, an employment of his by the employer and that there should be the relationship between the employer and him as between employer and employee or master and servant.

precedents.citation: Workmen v. The Management of Dimakuchi Tea Estate 3

anchor.surface_text: Workmen v. The Management of Dimakuchi Tea Estate 3 . In Dharangadhara Chemical Works Ltd., the appellants were lessees holding a licence for manufacturing salt on the demised lands. The salt was manufactured by a class of professional labourers, known as agarias, from rain water that got mixed up with saline matter in the soil.

precedents.case_name: Workmen v. The Management of Dimakuchi Tea Estate
precedents.cited_proposition: prior to 1956 when the definition of workman in the Act was further widened to include a person dismissed, discharged or retrenched in connection with, or as a consequence of the dispute or whose dismissal, discharge or retrenchment led to the dispute, a workman who had been discharged earlier and not during the dispute was not a workman within the meaning of the Act.
items relevant in fixation of fair wages

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the Labour Court held that the respondent was entitled to claim car allowance at Rs. 200 per month, Rs. 50 per month for telephone and news- papers and companypensation for 13 days leave, that the first two were parts of his wages, that his monthly remuneration was, therefore, Rs. 1,447 and gratuity equivalent to 51 months wages would have to be calculated on the basis of Rs. 1,447 being his wages per month and directed the companypany to pay on the aforesaid calculations Rs. 2,002 over and above Rs. 2,810.47 P. for which the companypany had issued the said cheque. The first contention raised by counsel for the company against the award was that the respondent, not being in the companys employment at the time he filed his claim in the Labour Court, was not a working journalist, and therefore, was not entitled to avail himself of the provisions of the Act.

outcome.relief_summary: Labour Court award upheld; respondent entitled to additional gratuity of Rs. 2,002 calculated including car allowance, value of free telephone and newspapers as part of wages, and compensation for 13 days leave
directions: pay Rs. 2,002 to the respondent over and above Rs. 2,810.47 already paid

edges.explanation: Holding h1 explicitly states that an ex-employee is a working journalist for the purposes of the controversy, directly addressing whether the respondent was entitled despite not being employed at claim filing.

anchor.surface_text: Since the definitions of ex employee in these two Acts were in language similar to the one used in the present Act, these decisions would be authorities for the view that an ex- employee would for the purposes of the present controversy be a working journalist.

In the result, the Labour Court held that the respondent was entitled to claim car allowance at Rs. 200 per month, Rs. 50 per month for telephone and news- papers and companypensation for 13 days leave, that the first two were parts of his wages, that his monthly remuneration was, therefore, Rs. 1,447 and gratuity equivalent to 51 months wages would have to be calculated on the basis of Rs. 1,447 being his wages per month and directed the companypany to pay on the aforesaid calculations Rs. 2,002 over and above Rs. 2,810.47 P. for which the companypany had issued the said cheque. The first contention raised by counsel for the company against the award was that the respondent, not being in the companys employment at the time he filed his claim in the Labour Court, was not a working journalist, and therefore, was not entitled to avail himself of the provisions of the Act.

edges.explanation: Holding h2 on the scheme of industrial acts to permit ex-employees to raise claims grounds the interpretation of Industrial Disputes Act S.2(k) as covering disputes regarding non-employment of ex-workmen.

anchor.surface_text: The scheme of all these acts dealing with industrial questions is to permit an ex-employee to avail of the benefits of their provisions, the only requirement being that the claim in dispute must be one which has arisen or accrued whilst the claimant was in the employment of the person against whom it is made.

anchor.surface_text: This position emerges from Roys reply dated December 5, 1963 to the respondents said letter of November 21, 1963 wherein the stand taken by Roy was that the respondent was, not entitled to compensation for leave, not because he had given up that claim when he had signed the said receipt, but because the companys rules did not permit such compensation,

In the result, the Labour Court held that the respondent was entitled to claim car allowance at Rs. 200 per month, Rs. 50 per month for telephone and news- papers and companypensation for 13 days leave, that the first two were parts of his wages, that his monthly remuneration was, therefore, Rs. 1,447 and gratuity equivalent to 51 months wages would have to be calculated on the basis of Rs. 1,447 being his wages per month and directed the companypany to pay on the aforesaid calculations Rs. 2,002 over and above Rs. 2,810.47 P. for which the companypany had issued the said cheque. The first contention raised by counsel for the company against the award was that the respondent, not being in the companys employment at the time he filed his claim in the Labour Court, was not a working journalist, and therefore, was not entitled to avail himself of the provisions of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The statements of the respondent in that letter having thus remained unchallenged, the Labour Court could not reject them. In these circumstances it becomes doubtful whether he could be said to have been estopped from making the said claims on the ground only of the said receipt, if that receipt was obtained, as alleged by him, under the stress of circumstances.

In the result, the Labour Court held that the respondent was entitled to claim car allowance at Rs. 200 per month, Rs. 50 per month for telephone and news- papers and companypensation for 13 days leave, that the first two were parts of his wages, that his monthly remuneration was, therefore, Rs. 1,447 and gratuity equivalent to 51 months wages would have to be calculated on the basis of Rs. 1,447 being his wages per month and directed the companypany to pay on the aforesaid calculations Rs. 2,002 over and above Rs. 2,810.47 P. for which the companypany had issued the said cheque. The first contention raised by counsel for the company against the award was that the respondent, not being in the companys employment at the time he filed his claim in the Labour Court, was not a working journalist, and therefore, was not entitled to avail himself of the provisions of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: So, far as the car allowance is concerned, there was, as aforesaid, nothing to suggest at it was paid to reimburse him of the expenses of conveyance which he would have to incur for discharging his duties as the special correspondent, or that it was anything else than an allowance within the meaning of s. 2 rr of that Act. It would, therefore, fall under the inclusive part

In the result, the Labour Court held that the respondent was entitled to claim car allowance at Rs. 200 per month, Rs. 50 per month for telephone and news- papers and companypensation for 13 days leave, that the first two were parts of his wages, that his monthly remuneration was, therefore, Rs. 1,447 and gratuity equivalent to 51 months wages would have to be calculated on the basis of Rs. 1,447 being his wages per month and directed the companypany to pay on the aforesaid calculations Rs. 2,002 over and above Rs. 2,810.47 P. for which the companypany had issued the said cheque. The first contention raised by counsel for the company against the award was that the respondent, not being in the companys employment at the time he filed his claim in the Labour Court, was not a working journalist, and therefore, was not entitled to avail himself of the provisions of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: Likewise, the benefit of the telephone and newspapers was allowed to the respondent not merely for the use thereof in connection with his employment or duties connected with it. Both the car allowance and the benefit of the free telephone and newspapers appear to have been allowed to him to directly reduce the expenditure which would otherwise have gone into his family budget

In the result, the Labour Court held that the respondent was entitled to claim car allowance at Rs. 200 per month, Rs. 50 per month for telephone and news- papers and companypensation for 13 days leave, that the first two were parts of his wages, that his monthly remuneration was, therefore, Rs. 1,447 and gratuity equivalent to 51 months wages would have to be calculated on the basis of Rs. 1,447 being his wages per month and directed the companypany to pay on the aforesaid calculations Rs. 2,002 over and above Rs. 2,810.47 P. for which the companypany had issued the said cheque. The first contention raised by counsel for the company against the award was that the respondent, not being in the companys employment at the time he filed his claim in the Labour Court, was not a working journalist, and therefore, was not entitled to avail himself of the provisions of the Act.
ondents wages and -had to be taken into calculations of the gratuity payable to him.

edges.explanation: Holding h7 concludes that telephone, newspapers, and related items are part of wages for gratuity calculation, directly addressing i4.

anchor.surface_text: That being the position, the two items could on the facts and circumstances of the present case be properly regarded as part of the respondents wages and had to be taken into calculations of the gratuity payable to him.

In the result, the Labour Court held that the respondent was entitled to claim car allowance at Rs. 200 per month, Rs. 50 per month for telephone and news- papers and companypensation for 13 days leave, that the first two were parts of his wages, that his monthly remuneration was, therefore, Rs. 1,447 and gratuity equivalent to 51 months wages would have to be calculated on the basis of Rs. 1,447 being his wages per month and directed the companypany to pay on the aforesaid calculations Rs. 2,002 over and above Rs. 2,810.47 P. for which the companypany had issued the said cheque. The first contention raised by counsel for the company against the award was that the respondent, not being in the companys employment at the time he filed his claim in the Labour Court, was not a working journalist, and therefore, was not entitled to avail himself of the provisions of the Act.
